STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 11, 2025
Lindsey Lassanske
MASON/OCEANA COUNTY DHHS
4081 W POLK RD,
HART, MI, 49420-8177
Re: License #: CP640201336
Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
July 11, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have the reevaluation completed
within 15 calendar days of the license expiration date as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
The agency is currently license but once all foster home providers are closed or
transferred, the agency will be merging with other licensed MDHHS offices and this
license will be closed.
2

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 6/11/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 8/7/2024. The agency was cited for 11 violations, none of which were
repeated this year. In 2023, 10 violations were established, none of which were
repeated this year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the previous year CAP had a positive impact overall. There has been a
noticeable improvement in quality contacts and successful completion of licensing
tasks. The assessment noted some barriers including a lack of available medical
and dental care. In addition, some contacts were missed due to circumstances
outside of staff control, such as frequent rescheduling and parents avoiding
workers. The agency has experienced a significant amount of change during the
review period, specifically a reconfiguration of county structures which has led to
changes in worker roles and case assignments.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were interviewed face-to-face at the agency. Staff expressed the
transition with office realignment has been somewhat challenging at times, but
they feel everyone worked together to do their part. No concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: The relative home was found to lack a carbon monoxide
detector.
Resolution: A carbon monoxide detector was provided to caregiver by licensing
worker. It was installed while staff was onsite and verified to be in working
3

condition. Two pictures showing the installed carbon monoxide detector were
provided as verification.
Safety Alert #2: A licensed foster home had a foster child sleeping in the
basement living room which has not been assessed as a bedroom in the home.
Resolution: The child was moved to an upstairs bedroom that meets licensing
requirements. A variance was submitted to DCWL in case the licensed foster
home would like to use that space as a bedroom in the future. After discussion
between the agency and licensed foster home it was decided to withdraw the
variance as the sleeping arrangements are now in compliance with licensing
rules.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
__________7/11/2025_______________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
